body.p:
Your letter of the 4th inst.
came to came to hand today and I was gratified
not a little to hear that your health is
“improving so nicely”. It was not altogether
gratifying however to learn that you are
feeling “doubtfulldoubtful about making a successful
canvass in Newport,” that “agents have been
canvassing in the place before” your arrival
Harvey of N Providence is the man I reserve.
I was not aware that Miss Gainsworth
was attempting to do anything.

Now as to what you have better do under
the circumstances, I can only say this,
if you see that it will not pay to tarry
for a few weeks, were I in your stead
I would go to Hartford or New Haven and
in this connection also I might name Martha's
Vineyard, in Mass. 28 or 30 miles from
New Bedford - as a summer resort and
watering place it stands very high. As your
health is improving this is every thing. With
good health you can make money, but
not so with bad health - So you have no
right to feel discouraged with your
visit down East. It is all as Providence
(not Providence in R.I.) would have
it perhaps, so take it calmly and the
end will all come out right.

In Newark & New Brunswick
N.J. on your way home, I judge it
would pay you to stop. The rest I will
leave you to fill up.

Carrie and the baby went yesterday
to Atlantic City, to comply with Mrs Jones'
invitation. Jones is still there quite sick
but hopes to be well enough by Saturday
to come home.

The rest of the family are
all well except I am in possession
of a desperate bad cold which I would
be pleased to get rid of very soon.
But we are not to have all sunshine
in this world. We must have clouds
and head winds occasionally. Our father
above is very good and will stand by
us faithfully if we will do right.
So let us be of good cheer.
